column4: why is it that what I fit on a 441gig raid 5 partition (ext3 on debian etchy) won't fit on my new ubuntu system with a 463g raid 5 partition (ext3)?
and I had 4% free on the old (441gig) drive
only 400gigs used
but it's taking up 439gigs when I rsync it over to the new system
Because more than 4% is reserved on the filesystem for superuser
ok, but why would it fit on one system and not another?
See my previous answer
so ubuntu is different in that case?
400gigs of data is now taking up 439 gigs when I rsyned it over to ubuntu
measuring all this apples to apples (df -h to df -h)
reiser4progs
I think that allows you to create the filesystem but not mount  it
reiserfsprogs as well
This package contains utilities to create, check, resize, and debug ReiserFS filesystems.
Did you also install kernel-patch-2.6-reiser4 ?
I can't find that package anywhere
On my box the reiserfs kernel module seems to have been built into the initram and it works to mount without needing to specify -t fstype.
rieser4? or just rieser?
I don't have any reiser4 systems yet, just reiser, so can't test right now
right, reiser3 works fine... but you can't mount reiser4, just create the file systems... real usefull *rolleyes*
Have you tried something as obvious as perhaps sudo mount -t reiser4 /dev/<whatever reiser4progs formatted drive> /mountpoint          ?
Sorry, stepped out for a second... yes I've tried that... it doesn't know that file type
There seems something interesting on the whole subject here http://forums.debian.net/viewtopic.php?t=11926&sid=8854c4b61836037d8c87cf210fef1018
yeah, I was hoping to keep my ubuntu kernel.. maybe just patch it... don't really care to start with a generic kernel :(
